data.title: Lakeshore Classic Movies
data.meta_description: Mickey Rooney borrows $20 from the till to take out a new girl, leading to more trouble.
data.text:
(upbeat music) (dramatic music) >> How's the pie?

>> Fine.

>> Buzz, how's the fishing these days?

>> It's not very good around here, but there's a big run of marlin off Tijuana.

>> Yeah?

>> I'm taking a party down there Sunday morning.

>> How do you like this guy?

He gets paid to go fishing while we slave over a hot carburetor.

>> You said it.

>> Hey, Dan, we got room for one more.

Why don't you come along?

>> When are you gonna get back?

>> Late Monday night.

>> Monday night, that lets me out.

I couldn't get Monday off.

>> You could get away if you wanted to.

You just don't want to miss spending Sunday with the girlfriend.

>> Helen?

Nah, they busted up a couple of months ago.

By the way, she called you again this morning.

>> She did?

>> I told her you wasn't in for the 19th time.

>> Good, good.

>> How do you like this guy?

There's a dame I'd trade my right arm for, and he gives her the runaround.

>> Maybe he's found a new dish.

>> I spent four years in the Navy fighting for freedom.

Why get anchored down now?

Besides, she was getting too serious.

>> There were wedding bells, huh?

>> They were getting louder and louder.

I figure she's too nice to string along.

She won't take no for an answer.

>> Some dames are sure hard to shake off.

I once knew a blonde.

Boy, she-- >> And her name was Margie.

>> How did you know?

>> We've heard this story a dozen times.

>> A couple of dozen times.

>> Hey, we better be getting back or old man Mackey will blow a fuse.

>> Right.

Here, that's for you.

Hey.

Some babe.

>> Yeah.

>> Yeah.

>> See you later, fellas.

Little work to do.

You new here, honey?

>> 65 out of a dollar.

>> What time do you get off tonight?

6:30, 7:00?

>> Don't forget your change.

>> I happen to have my autograph book here with me.

Name and address?

>> I'm afraid you've made a mistake.

I don't come with the merchant's lunch.

>> Oh, now don't be like that.

I think you're wonderful.

Anything wrong in that?

>> No, but-- >> Well, then how about you and me tonight, huh?

>> I work tonight.

>> Till when?

>> Till 9:30.

You like Red Nichols and his outfit?

>> Yeah, I think they're great.

>> They're playing over at the music bar on the pier.

I thought I'd pick you up after 9:30, and we'll go over and give them a listen, okay?

>> Okay.

>> See you tonight.

>> 75 out of one.

>> Hey, Chuck.

>> Yeah?

>> I just remembered something.

>> Remembered what?

>> It's five days until payday, and I'm flat busted.

How are you holding?

>> I'm scratchin'.

>> Me too.

Well, I gotta figure out some way to get some geedis, or how else am I gonna take that gorgeous creature out to the music bar?

>> Why don't you ask old man Mackey for an advance?

>> Oh, that old guy.

He wouldn't give you the sweat off his glasses.

>> Yeah, he's sure a mean old buzzard.

>> Hey, buzzard.

I'm glad you said that.

Buzz Larson owes me twenty bucks.

>> Why don't you call him up down at the dock?

>> My friend, you have just read my mind.

(Dan whistling) Hello, is Buzz Larson there, please?

Oh, hello, Buzz.

Hiya, boy, this is Dan.

Listen, could you let me have that twenty bucks you owe me?

Oh, that's swell.

Believe me, you're a life saver.

I'll be down tonight and pick it up.

Huh?

Tomorrow?

Oh, wait a minute, boy.

I need it right away.

You don't get paid until tomorrow.

Yeah, I understand, sure.

Okay, all right.

Thanks anyway, kid.

Bye.

>> Who left that light on in the washroom?

>> Not me.

>> Well, it was one of you fellas.

You're all alike.

You don't care what you do with my money.

You think I own stock in the power company?

>> So she said to me, "I want to speak to the supervisor."

So I said, "One moment, please."

And then I said, "Yes, this is the supervisor speaking."

Helen Coggin, are you listening to me?

>> Yeah.

>> I don't think you've heard one word.

You just seem to be walking around in a dream lately.

>> Oh, Millie, I think I'll say goodbye to you here.

There are some things I have to get.

>> What things?

Where?

>> Oh, just some things over on State Street.

>> I know where you're going, Helen, and you're making a big mistake.

If he wants to see you, he knows your telephone number.

>> I know, but I-- >> But nothing.

You're making a fool of yourself.

>> I don't think I am.

Goodbye, Millie.

>> Well, when you need it fast sometimes, you haven't got time.

>> A lighter.

>> What?

>> A standard lighter.

>> Yeah, okay.

No, no, not you, Ed.

Yeah, sure.

Well, if you haven't got it, you can't lend it to me.

Yeah, all right.

Thanks a lot, bye.

>> Did you reach Buzz?

>> Yeah, I called him, Ray Chris, and Jimmy Cook, all of 'em.

None of 'em have it.

>> Too bad.

>> $1.03.

>> Exact change.

>> There you go.

Nobody checks my cash except this once-a-week bookkeeper, and he don't come around till Thursday.

I could put it back before Thursday.

I could put it back tomorrow as soon as I get that twenty bucks from Buzz.

(bell ringing) (time clock ringing) >> Dan.

Oh, Danny.

>> Oh, hello, Helen.

>> Hello, Danny.

This is a surprise.

>> Yeah.

Yeah, how's every little thing?

>> Just fine.

>> That's good.

Well, I'll see you later, huh?

>> Have you been dancing lately?

>> Yeah, I went last Saturday.

>> Do you ever go hiking anymore?

>> Once in a while.

>> Do you remember the Sunday we hiked up Pioneer Canyon?

>> Yeah.

>> Didn't we have fun?

>> Yeah, we had lots of fun.

>> Well, Danny, will you give me a ring sometime?

>> Sure, I'll give you a ring, and we'll get together real soon.

Well, I'll see you later.

I'll give you a ring soon.

(horn honking) Taxi, lady?

>> Where's your meter?

>> I'll figure out the fare as we go along.

>> You might overcharge me.

>> I might at that.

Hop in, honey.

Where would you like to go?

>> Let's go downtown, window shopping.

>> How dull can you get?

>> Well, that's what I want to do.

We can do something else later.

>> You have a deal, honey.

(engine sputtering) (engine rumbling) >> It's still here.

>> Nice-looking coat.

Bet they'd suck you at least a thousand bucks for a coat like that.

>> Are you kidding?

Why, that's mink.

It's a bargain at two thousand.

Isn't that the most beautiful thing you've ever seen in your life?

>> Oh, it's not bad.

Are you thinking on buying it?

>> I want that coat, and I'm gonna get it.

>> For two thousand dollars?

>> For whatever it takes.

>> Say, wait a minute.

You really do want it, don't you?

>> You bet I do.

(upbeat music) (patrons chattering) >> You're kidding.

Wait a minute, wait a minute.

>> Huh?

>> Ah, they're blue.

>> Huh uh, brown.

♪ Oh, but there's blues in your big brown eyes ♪ >> Oh, you sing too.

>> Only for you, honey.

>> Shall we go?

>> Closed Mondays.

How do you like that?

>> Are you sure you didn't happen to know it was closed when you invited me?

>> Now wait a minute.

Would I do a thing like that?

Now I'll take you anyplace you want to go.

Name it, and you can have it.

>> All right.

All right, I know a place where I'd like to go.

>> Boys: Bang, bang, bang, bang, bang, bang, bang!

>> Hey, you, get out of here!

>> Bang, bang, bang, bang!

>> I'll catch you.

You silly brats, you hear me?

I'll save you all the trouble of growing up.

What's the matter?

Cut that out.

You want to break the machine?

>> Hello, Nick.

>> Oh, it's you.

>> Gimme a nickel, Danny.

I'll show you how to beat this game.

>> Dan: Wait a minute.

>> One ball.

Hey, Nick, pay me.

I hit the jackpot.

>> Here.

That's all for you.

>> Hey, wait a minute.

Go ahead, honey, play it as much as you want.

>> Take it easy, Danny.

I can handle Nick myself.

I used to work here, didn't I, Nick?

>> Yeah.

Would you come back, huh?

>> It's still in the window, Nick.

I saw it yesterday.

>> Are you crazy?

What do you think I am, a millionaire?

>> What's going on here?

>> Oh, let's skip it.

Come on, we'll have our pictures taken.

Come on.

See you later, Nick.

>> Who goes first?

>> We both go.

>> What do you want?

>> Gimme a half a buck's worth of nickels.

>> Okay, Admiral.

Now what do you want?

>> There's only nine nickels there, buddy.

>> Yeah?

Who's cheating who?

>> What?

>> Look, you got your nickel, haven't you?

Hit the road.

>> Why, hello, Nick.

>> Look, I've got rules in this house.

That goes for you too.

If you want to pull that kind of stuff, go somewhere else.

Come on, beat it.

Beat it!

>> Come on, Vera, let's get out of this crummy joint.

>> Goodbye, Nick.

(upbeat music) (surf crashing) See that big star right there?

>> Yeah.

>> That's Betelgeuse.

>> Who?

>> Betelgeuse.

Betelgeuse Dave used to call it.

>> Dave?

Who's Dave?

>> Oh, a fella I used to know.

He taught me the names of all the stars.

You know, I never saw a star until I was 16?

>> How come?

>> I was raised in a steel town in West Virginia, and you couldn't see the sky for the smoke.

So I ran away.

>> Funny, I ran away from home too.

That was a long, long time ago.

What did you do after you ran away from home?

>> Oh, I was a car hop for a while, waitress in a beer joint, clerk in a five and ten, cashier in a coffee shop.

It's not what you run away to.

It's what you run away from.

>> I ran away from a farm and the belt the old man used to whip me with.

That old man sure was free with that belt.

>> Oh, I ran away from a lot of things.

Ma getting drunk all the time and never having any decent clothes to wear.

And the boarders, especially those boarders.

They wouldn't leave me alone.

>> Must have been tough.

>> I learned to handle them after a while.

>> Think you can handle me?

>> Sure.

I can handle you easy.

>> Yeah?

Hello, is Buzz there?

He what?

Took a fishing party, huh?

When will he be back?

No, no, nevermind, I'll... All right.

I'll call him later.

Bye.

The bookkeeper.

What's he doing here two days ahead of time?

If he finds out I'm short, he'll tell the old man.

The old man's mean enough to send a guy to jail just for laughs.

I gotta get twenty bucks in a hurry.

How about that salary loan outfit?

The one that's always yackin' on the radio.

Walk in with an honest face, walk out with a pocket full of dough.

I must have walked in with the wrong face.

A couple of days to check my references.

I haven't got any references, and I haven't got a couple of days.

Can I have it for a dollar down like it says in the window?

>> As soon as we've checked up on your credit.

>> Dan: Credit, oh.

Oh, I can't wait that long.

>> Oh, wait a minute.

You got a charge account in town?

>> No, I...

Yes.

Yes, I have at the Hub.

At the Hub where I buy my clothes.

>> I tell you what I'll do.

I'll call their credit manager, and if he says you're okay, you can take the watch right with you, okay?

Now there, let's get it on and show you what it looks like.

>> How much could you let me have on this ticker?

>> $30 do you any good?

>> $30 will be fine.

>> Any better than last week?

>> I don't know yet, Mr. Mackey.

I'll let you know.

>> Oh, about that other matter.

See if you can't find a way to make it a business deduction.

>> I'll think about it, Mr. Mackey.

>> Hi, George.

>> Hi, Danny.

>> You're here kind of early this week, aren't you?

>> The old man sent for me.

He had some tax reports for me to get out.

>> Oh.

>> And I figured as long as I was here, I'd get my Thursday work done.

Say, Dan, I just checked the register, and it's $20 short.

>> Well, maybe you could have made a mistake or something.

>> No, I checked it twice.

>> Well, you know sometimes the money gets stuck in the money sack down there.

Yeah.

Yeah, here it is.

See?

>> But I looked in the money sack.

>> You just didn't look good enough.

Can I do anything for you, sir?

>> Are you Dan Brady?

>> Yeah.

>> I'm Moriarity, California Investigation Service.

You bought a watch yesterday at Jay's Jewelers, didn't you?

>> Yeah, I did.

>> And took it straight to Uncle John's and hocked it?

>> What if I did?

>> Don't play dumb.

Why would you buy a watch for $100 dollars and hock it the same day for 30?

>> Well, I-- >> Because you don't intend to pay the hundred, that's why.

>> Now wait a minute, don't holler before you're hurt, pal.

I signed up to pay that thing ten bucks a month.

And when the month's up, I'll pay him the ten bucks.

>> Oh no, you won't.

Because Jay Jewelers don't think you're gonna here when the month's up.

They think you're gonna skip town.

So you'll pay up now, or Jay's gonna swear out a warrant.

>> A warrant?

Warrant for what?

>> I'll give it to you in words of one syllable, my friend.

When you buy something on the installment plan, you sign what they call a conditional sales contract.

>> Dan: Yeah?

>> This contract says that the watch, the radio, or the easy chair don't belong to you until you make your last payment.

It says that if you sell, mortgage, or hock something you don't own yet, you're guilty of larceny.

And a $100 dollar watch is grand larceny.

That's three years in the penitentiary in this state.

>> Oh, you're kiddin' me, aren't you?

>> Kiddin', me?

Not on your life.

You signed a contract like this, didn't you?

>> Yeah.

>> Read what it says right there.

>> Debt is payable-- >> Within 24 hours or charges will be brought.

>> Look, I can't get a hold of a hundred bucks, I mean, just like that right away.

>> Well, you better dig it up somewhere.

Because if you don't pay up by noon tomorrow, a little man's gonna call on you with a big warrant.

That's all, brother, until noon tomorrow.

>> Hey, Chuck.

>> Yeah?

>> What does a guy do when he needs lots of dough?

>> Me, I usually hock my watch.

>> That's a great idea.

Maybe I can get some dough on my jalopy.

I wonder how much they'll give me for it.

Nah, no dice.

What good is three hundred bucks?

I still owe the finance company 350.

(upbeat music) By half past eight, I'd tried everything I could think of, and I still hadn't raised $100 dollars.

I hadn't raised a buck and a quarter.

So I threw in the towel and headed for Phil's Place to knock off a couple of beers.

The longer I sat on that silly stool, the more I felt like slugging somebody.

I could've socked old man Mackey for being so tight, or the guy in the jewelry store for sending Moriarity after me, or the fellow standing next to me at the bar.

Because he had money in his pocket, and I didn't.

>> How much do I owe you, Phil?

>> 3.60, Shorty.

>> Okay, I gotta get home before the old lady chops my ears off.

>> Haven't you got something smaller?

This one's a 50.

>> Oh, is it?

Well, how's this one?

>> That's another 50.

Here, let me look.

There's a five right there on top.

>> Oh, this one.

>> Yeah.

>> Just keep the change.

I gotta get home before the old lady slaps me down.

Who?

>> Your wife.

>> Oh, yeah.

Yeah, the old lady.

Good night, Phil.

>> So long, Shorty.

>> How's a joker like that rate all that dough?

>> Shorty?

He runs the bingo games.

Do the suckers keep him happy.

Another beer, Danny?

>> No, that's all, Phil.

>> Hi, Romy, how's things?

>> Hi, Shorty, how was your day?

>> Okay.

>> Oh, you're a nice boy.

Let me tell your fortune.

Maybe you got big warnings.

>> Leave me alone, will you?

>> Ah, go fall on your face, you jerk.

Tell your fortune?

♪ I've got a mule and her name is Sal ♪ ♪ 15 miles on the Erie Canal ♪ ♪ 15 miles on the Erie Canal ♪ ♪ I've got a mule and her name is Sal ♪ ♪ 15 miles on the Erie Canal ♪ ♪ She's a good old worker and a good old pal ♪ ♪ 15 miles on the Erie Canal ♪ ♪ She's a good old worker and a good old pal ♪ ♪ 15 miles on the Erie Canal ♪ ♪ On the Erie Canal ♪ >> All right, reach.

Reach, come on.

I'm not kiddin' you.

Let's go.

All right, come on, in the back.

Down on the floor.

Hurry up, get in.

(woman screams) (crowd chattering) (whistle ringing) (siren blaring) Helen!

Oh, Helen!

Hiya, chum.

Long time, no see.

Hiya, Millie.

>> Hello.

>> Gee, Dan, it's wonderful to see you.

>> Well, what are we waiting for, huh?

>> What's your hurry tonight?

I never saw you run after anybody before.

>> Oh, Millie, please.

>> Hey, take it easy.

What's the rush?

Nobody's chasing us.

>> Yeah, that's right.

Nobody's chasing us.

We've got all night, haven't we?

>> Sure, we have.

>> Maybe you've got all night.

Me and Helen, we only got five minutes till the last show.

Loges or general?

>> Millie, I almost forgot.

I've already seen this picture.

I saw it when I was downtown at the Palace.

>> But you said... Oh, I got it.

You wouldn't mind if I went alone, would you?

>> No, I wouldn't mind.

>> I didn't think so.

Goodbye then.

>> Goodbye.

>> Gee, Dan, this is like old times.

>> Yeah.

Let's go on the rollercoaster and the chutes and the dipper.

Let's go on everything.

>> All right.

My knees were really shaking back there.

I thought the cops would bust out of that alley any minute.

But now I'm in the clear with heavy dough in my pocket.

I can pay off that jewelry store and have enough left over to show Vera the biggest time she ever had.

Vera!

I've got a date with her tonight.

I promised to meet her at Nick's place.

What time is it?

>> It's 25 to 10:00.

>> Holy smoke, I promised to meet a guy a half hour ago.

I'm kind of late.

I'm sorry, kid.

Can I walk you to the bus or something?

>> Oh, you don't have to, Danny.

I can get home by myself.

>> Well, I'll give you a ring, and we'll get together sometime soon.

I'll see you later, chum.

>> And don't come back.

I want my $50.

>> Do me a favor, will you?

Drop dead.

>> Nick!

>> Vera: Stop it!

>> Take your jerk hands off her.

Take your hands off of her.

Did you hear me?

>> I don't like to be pushed around.

I just don't like it.

>> Danny!

(men grunting) (punch cracking) (punch cracking) >> What's all this about $50?

>> It wasn't a loan.

It was a present.

>> I don't want you taking $50 from a guy like this ever.

Let's get out of here.

(upbeat carnival music) (jazzy music) Waiter, waiter, two more of these.

>> When are you gonna tell me what we're celebrating?

>> Are we supposed to be celebrating something?

>> Oh, has to be.

Last night you were spending dollar bills, and tonight it's fifties.

>> I won at the crap game.

>> Sure it wasn't bingo?

>> Waiter: Two champagne cocktails.

>> What do you mean bingo?

>> Just thought you might have won it from Shorty McCabe.

>> What gave you that idea?

>> Maybe it was Evelyn.

>> Evelyn?

Who's Evelyn?

>> Bookkeeper in the movie house.

She saw Shorty lose it in the auto park.

>> What do you know about this?

>> Oh, she just came into Nick's place to phone the cops.

>> Cops?

What'd she say?

>> Vera, long time, no see.

How about a dance?

>> No thanks.

>> Your boyfriend won't mind.

>> No thanks.

>> Can I buy you both a drink?

>> No.

>> No.

>> Isn't there anything I can do for you?

>> Yeah, blow.

>> You heard her.

What did she say?

>> Danny!

She said she saw the guy who did it with a handkerchief around his face.

He took Shorty for his bankroll.

Didn't he?

>> How do I know?

>> Just thought you might have heard about it.

Anyhow, if it was me and I'd won any $50 bills, I wouldn't go spending them around the pier.

>> Yeah?

Why not?

>> Because everyone around knows that Shorty carries fifties.

>> Look, I don't know any guy named Shorty.

And I won this dough in a crap game, see?

>> Oh, now sure you did.

Sure you did, Danny.

Let's dance a little, huh?

>> That's more like it.

>> Only we won't spend the fifties, will we?

>> No.

No, we won't spend the fifties.

40, 60, 80, 100.

There's $100 dollars.

There's your dough.

>> And there's your contract.

So long, Brady.

>> So long.

(phone ringing) Mackey Motor.

Who?

This is him speaking.

How would I like to what?

How would you like to take a big jump off the pier?

>> No, I don't like to take a jump off the pier.

But you better come and see me or else.

>> Or else what?

>> Or else something is gonna happen to you.

To you, Danny boy.

>> What's on your mind?

And it better be good.

>> Oh, it's very good.

You know, last night the prizefighter, big prizefighter, he left something here.

I picked it up, picked it up where you left it.

It's got a knot in it.

You know, like you use for a mask or something.

>> I don't know what you're talking about.

>> No?

>> No.

But I'll take it just for luck.

>> Sure, sure, you keep my handkerchief.

I keep your handkerchief.

Same knot, only your handkerchief got blood on it.

>> So what?

>> Did you ever hear anybody say money talks?

$50 bills, they talk very loud.

Big bills.

What do they say?

Say Shorty McCabe, Shorty McCabe.

Yeah, that's what it says, Shorty McCabe.

>> What's your angle?

What are you trying to tell me?

>> I'm telling you about a holdup.

You see, Evelyn from the picture show, she saw the man get robbed and she got a very good look at the guy who did it.

She thinks she can identify him very easy.

Nice girl.

You want me to call her?

>> Wait a minute.

Put it down.

If you're so sure that I was mixed up in this thing, why don't you call the cops?

>> Cops?

Oh no, no.

I'm a businessman.

See, Danny boy, I think I can do business with you very nice.

>> What kind of business do you think you can do with me?

>> Automobile business.

You get me a new car, and I don't know nothin'.

Just nothin'.

>> A new car?

I couldn't get a new car if I wanted to.

>> Oh, you can get a new car same way you got the $50 bill.

>> Are you nuts?

>> Nuts, me?

No, I don't think so.

>> Davis.

>> Chuck: Yes?

>> Here are the plates for the green sedan.

See that it's ready for delivery in the morning.

>> Yes, sir.

>> Oh, and Davis, don't let me catch you putting in ten gallons of gas this time.

Six is plenty.

>> Yes, sir.

>> Dan: There goes the last new car we'll have this month.

I've got to get it tonight or blow town tomorrow.

Even if I blow town, they'll probably catch up with me.

Oh boy, am I in a mess.

>> Hey, Dan.

Dan, I was just thinking that if you're not gonna take Helen out anymore, I thought maybe I'd give her a call sometime.

>> Yeah, sure.

Why don't you do that, Chuck?

(dramatic music) (upbeat carnival music) Hey, fella, this thing is stuck back here.

>> Let me see what it is.

>> It's the green sedan on Second and California Street.

It's got license plates.

>> That's fine.

Well, I promised you I know nothing.

Absolutely nothing.

>> Wait.

>> What's the matter?

>> I want the handkerchief.

>> Yeah.

You let go of this and I-- >> All right.

You let go and I'll let go.

>> Okay.

>> What are you gonna do with the car?

>> That's none of your business, Danny boy, but I'll tell you I sold it to a gambler friend of mine.

He's driving it home to Nevada.

>> You see that he does.

I don't want it around town here.

It's liable to get me in a jam.

>> Don't worry, he's going home tonight.

>> No slip-ups.

>> Okay.

>> Okay.

>> Brady.

>> Yeah?

>> Now I know who took that green sedan.

>> You do?

>> Yeah, I could tell the police about it right this minute.

But I don't know whether that would help me get back the car or not, you understand?

>> No, I don't.

>> Now I'm not interested in sending anybody to jail, Brady.

I'm interested in getting back that car.

>> I don't know why you're telling me all this, Mr. Mackey.

>> Oh, yes you do.

An employee of this firm stole that sedan, and I happen to know who it is because he was seen.

>> If you're trying to pin this thing on me, Mr. Mackey-- >> Now don't try to run any bluffs, Brady.

>> How many times do I have to tell you?

>> You don't have to tell me anything.

All you have to do is to get that car down here parked out in front before I get down tomorrow.

>> What if I haven't got it?

What if I don't know where it is?

>> But you did have it, and you do know where it is.

>> Well, I don't anymore!

>> If you can't return the car, you'll have to pay for it.

$3,000.

>> $3,000?

Why, it only lists for 1,950.

>> You don't think I'd sell to you at list?

>> $3,000, where would a guy like me get any dough like that?

>> Oh, most everybody's got a family someplace.

Why, folks would go to a lot of trouble to keep a man out of jail.

>> Not mine.

>> Now look, I'll give you 24 hours, Brady.

I want the money or I want the automobile.

Now let me give you some warning.

Don't you try to leave town.

>> $3,000.

It might as well been three million.

I tried to remember who could have seen me in the green sedan.

Nobody had known I had it except Nick.

Nick!

Maybe that was who told the old man.

Nick hated me.

He'd cut my throat for a nickel.

>> Hey, what's the matter with you tonight?

You look like you lost your last friend.

>> How would you like to go to Texas, honey, right now, right away?

>> Are you kiddin'?

>> I'm on the level.

>> Oh, what's the matter with California?

Weather getting too warm?

(dishes clattering) >> I'll tell you about it later.

So I'm in a worse jam than ever.
